author: timbeiko
content:
I think the block gas limit encapsulates multiple concerns, some of which stay post-merge, i.e.:
- long term cost of running a node (w/o massive DB improvements) vs. short term costs of using Ethereum
- risk of DoS transactions stalling the network (perhaps can be mitigated, but pre-merge miners could be paid out of band to do this and we can't stop them)
- possible performance degradation based on the state size, again, w/o DB improvements
